briefing:
Here‚Äôs a tightened, clearer version of the briefing with clearer structure, sharper curation, and more practical takeaways.

What's happening (top points)
- Benchmarks & capability: ARC-AGI-1/2 are saturated ‚Äî benchmark designers are pushing tests toward Millennium‚ÄëProblem‚Äìlevel math and other unsolved problems to stress frontier models.
- Capability overhang: OpenAI says model potential currently outstrips typical deployments. Expect stronger pushes to use reasoning models in healthcare, business workflows, and everyday apps in 2026.
- Labor signal: US programmer employment down ~27.5% over two years ‚Äî a strong indicator that code-writing roles are shifting, with more automation/agent work replacing some developer tasks.
- Chips & supply chain: Nvidia is on track to become TSMC‚Äôs largest customer in 2026 (~20% of revenue), signaling concentrated demand for AI wafers and supply‚Äëchain pressure.
- Robotics & automation scaling: Rapid robotic deployments ‚Äî humanoid Linkerbot assembly demos, Chinese solar farms using robotic arms, and GITAI field tests for outdoor construction work.
- Bio + ML tools: Columbia researchers demonstrated programmable in‚Äëvivo DNA methylation editing (epigenetic control), showing faster integration of wet‚Äëlab tools with ML-driven workflows.
- New developer/product tools: Devin (AI teammate that takes tickets, writes code, runs tests, opens PRs), Windsurf (live edit/agent monitoring), TwelveLabs (searchable video summaries), NotebookLM Reports, and Ruby 4.
- [SPONSORED] DELVE CUA: agent that automates compliance screenshot capture and attachments for controls and audit trails.

What this means (practical takeaways)
- If you run product or engineering: start proof‚Äëof‚Äëconcepts that put reasoning models into core workflows (triage, clinical decision support, contract review). The capability overhang means the models are ready ‚Äî the bottleneck is safe, monitored deployment.
- For dev teams: plan for agent-assisted development. Build CI hooks, test automation, and PR review flows that include AI-generated changes ‚Äî and validate outputs with human reviewers and coverage tests.
- For infra/ops: expect more demand for inference capacity and supply‚Äëchain sensitivity. Consider multi‚Äëvendor wafer/instance strategies and budget for larger GPU/accelerator needs in 2026.
- For compliance/security: add observability, audit logs, and verifiable artifacts to agent workflows. Evaluate tools like DELVE CUA for automated evidence capture, and require human‚Äëin‚Äëthe‚Äëloop gating on high‚Äërisk actions.
- For product/UX: embed assistants into shared, persistent contexts (group chat, projects, memories). Multi‚Äëuser features and workspace memory increase stickiness more than raw model quality.
- For leadership/HR: prepare workforce transition plans. Upskill teams to supervise, validate, and orchestrate AI agents rather than only to code from scratch.
- For bio/health teams: treat programmable epigenetic editing as a technology risk/opportunity ‚Äî coordinate with domain experts and regulatory teams before planning product moves that depend on in‚Äëvivo capabilities.

Quick actions to take this week
1. Kick off one small POC that adds a reasoning model to an existing workflow (customer triage, code review, or clinical note summarization). Limit scope and define success metrics.
2. Add agent observability basics: request/response logging, change diffs, and an approval step for any agent that modifies production artifacts.
3. Revisit vendor/infrastructure exposure: map major suppliers (GPUs/chips) and identify a contingency if a single supplier‚Äôs capacity becomes constrained.

Tone/accuracy notes
- Kept claims to what sources report (benchmarks shifting, employment drop, Nvidia/TSMC data, robotics, tools, Columbia bio result).
- Marked sponsored item explicitly.
- Avoided speculative leaps about imminent job obsolescence or exaggerated timelines.

If you want, I can convert the ‚ÄúQuick actions‚Äù into a one‚Äëpage checklist for your engineering, product, or compliance teams.
linkedin_content:
LinkedIn Post Ideas ‚Äî TOP 3

1) Topic Title: Turn the Capability Overhang into an Enterprise Edge  
- Why It Resonates: Founders can capture unused model reasoning today by wiring reasoning agents into one high-value workflow and outperform competitors who wait.  
- Based on Theme(s): OpenAI capability overhang; deployment gap; reasoning models entering healthcare/business workflows; enterprise deployment tooling.

2) Topic Title: Build Agent‚ÄëFirst Teams as Code Jobs Shrink  
- Why It Resonates: Hiring only coders risks falling behind ‚Äî startups that create roles around agents (trainers, reliability, product managers) ship faster with fewer traditional tickets.  
- Based on Theme(s): Declining programmer employment; SME reliance on AI agents; tools like Devin and Windsurf; automation trends.

3) Topic Title: Make Agents Sticky with Shared Memory & Multi‚ÄëUser Workspaces  
- Why It Resonates: Network effects for agents come from shared context and team workflows (memories, multi-user sessions), not just model size ‚Äî that‚Äôs how you get daily reuse.  
- Based on Theme(s): ChatGPT group chats; Projects & Memories; Windsurf multi-agent sessions; embedding agents into workflows.

Full LinkedIn Posts

Post 1 ‚Äî Turn the Capability Overhang into an Enterprise Edge
Your AI can do more than your org asks it to. üöÄüß†
There‚Äôs a capability overhang in today‚Äôs models ‚Äî they can reason beyond most deployed workflows.
Pick one high-value, low-risk process this quarter.
Examples: claims triage, invoice reconciliation, clinical note summarization.
Prototype a reasoning agent in 2‚Äì6 weeks:
1) Define inputs/outputs and success metrics (time saved, error %, approval rate).  
2) Keep a human in the loop for edge cases.  
3) Add simple safety checks, logging, and an audit trail.  
Measure: aim for 30‚Äì50% time reduction or a clear drop in manual errors.
If it works, replicate the pattern across adjacent workflows.
Takeaway: ship one reasoning pilot this quarter. What workflow would you hand to an agent first? Reply below. üìà

Post 2 ‚Äî Build Agent‚ÄëFirst Teams as Code Jobs Shrink
Hiring only coders is a high-risk play for the next decade. ü§ñüõ†Ô∏è
Programmer headcount is shifting ‚Äî agents change who does the work.
Start redesigning teams now:
- Create roles: agent trainer (data + prompts), agent reliability engineer (monitoring + fallbacks), agent product manager (workflow integration).  
- Use tools like Devin for agent dev and Windsurf for multi-agent orchestration.  
- Invest in prompt design, evaluation frameworks, and rollback procedures.
Measure success by faster delivery, fewer traditional tickets, and lower MTTR on agent failures.
Takeaway: restructure one team for agents this quarter. What role would you hire first? Share one change. üîÅ

Post 3 ‚Äî Make Agents Sticky with Shared Memory & Multi‚ÄëUser Workspaces
Sticky agents live in your team‚Äôs context, not just in a bigger model. üí¨üîó
Network effects come from shared memories and multi-user workflows.
Start small ‚Äî one project, two weeks:
1) Add a shared memory for a project (meeting_summaries, decisions, owners, deadlines).  
2) Have the agent summarize meetings and push action items to your task tracker.  
3) Track reuse: did teammates call the agent next week?
Connect the agent to docs and tasks so it becomes the go‚Äëto helper.
Measure retention and repeat usage ‚Äî small shared wins compound into real network effects.
Takeaway: build one shared memory and test reuse in 2 weeks. Want a simple memory schema to try? DM me and I‚Äôll send a template. ‚úâÔ∏è
newsletter_summaries:
**Welcome to December 26, 2025** (from "Dr. Alex Wissner-Gross from The Innermost Loop" <theinnermostloop@substack.com>)
Industry News:
  - ARC-AGI-1 and ARC-AGI-2 benchmarks saturated; next benchmark shifts to Millennium Problem complexity and unsolved mathematics limits.
  - OpenAI reports a capability overhang between model potential and actual usage, pushing reasoning models more into healthcare, business, and daily life in 2026.
  - US programmer employment down 27.5% over two years, signaling potential long-term obsolescence in software development roles.
  - Nvidia projected to displace Apple as TSMC‚Äôs largest customer in 2026, accounting for about 20% of revenue, signaling supply-chain dominance shifts.
  - China enforces the world‚Äôs first mandatory EV energy efficiency standard starting 2026, with nine European nations at ~25% EV adoption.
New Tools:
  - PoPE (Polar Coordinate Positional Embedding) unveiled by J√ºrgen Schmidhuber, a geometric fix to the Transformer that boosts performance across domains.
  - First programmable in-vivo DNA methylation editing demonstrated by Columbia researchers, enabling precise epigenetic control.
  - Automation and robotics trend highlighted by Linkerbot humanoids assembling hands in Beijing, illustrating rapid advances in robotic self-replication concepts.
  - OpenAI capability overhang noted as a deployment motivation, implying increased tooling and reasoning model usage in enterprise settings.
  - Columbia and partners‚Äô epigenetic editing work referenced as a tool-facing advancement in bio-AI interfaces and data-to-insight pipelines.
Insights:
  - The move to Millennium Problem complexity suggests traditional human benchmarks will no longer bound frontier AI capabilities; plan for new evaluation criteria.
  - Labor-market shifts imply SMEs may increasingly rely on AI agents for core software and automation tasks as traditional coding roles contract.
  - A persistent deployment gap (capability overhang) may justify earlier, broader integration of reasoning models in business workflows in 2026.
  - Capital reallocation toward AI infrastructure (infrastructure finance) indicates opportunities for SMEs to partner with or leverage specialized AI platforms.
  - Regulatory and safety milestones (superhuman safety claims and autonomous aviation events) underscore the need for robust risk controls in agent deployments.

**üò∫ Why you underestimated China (and why you shouldn't)** (from The Neuron <theneuron@newsletter.theneurondaily.com>)
Industry News:
  - Chinese solar farms now deploy robotic arms for faster, safer panel installation and uneven terrain handling, enabling scale beyond flat land.
  - Japanese startup GITAI field-tested outdoor construction robots capable of deploying panels and welding in outdoor conditions.
  - OpenAI launched ChatGPT group chats for up to 20 participants across all plan tiers.
  - TSMC accelerates overseas chipmaking to reduce exposure to potential Taiwan-related geopolitical risk.
  - OpenAI‚Äôs profitability is not expected before 2029 amid large infrastructure investments and platform losses.
New Tools:
  - TwelveLabs turns your video library into searchable, plain-English summaries; free to try, usage-based after.
  - Koah lets you insert contextual ads into chat apps to monetize conversations without subscriptions.
  - Devin functions as a software teammate that can take a ticket, write code, run tests, and open a PR.
  - Windsurf is a code editor that applies changes in plain English and previews live edits.
  - NotebookLM Reports converts uploaded sources into structured outputs like study guides, glossaries, or blogs; free to try.
Insights:
  - iMessage integration could make ChatGPT a native group-chat assistant rather than a standalone app.
  - AI network effects hinge on embedding into workflows and social networks, not just model capabilities.
  - Playable, multi-user features and collaborative workspaces could create durable AI stickiness beyond basic chat.
  - A persistent, shared workspace model could accumulate knowledge over time, strengthening team workflows with AI.
  - Projects and Memories are highlighted as key differentiators for AI platforms impacting adoption and retention.

**Gmail address changes üìß, ChatGPT formatting blocks ü§ñ, Ruby 4 ‚ô¶Ô∏è** (from TLDR <dan@tldrnewsletter.com>)
Industry News:
  - Google is gradually rolling out the option to change a Gmail address to a new one (up to three times).
  - OpenAI has rolled out a new formatting feature that makes ChatGPT's UI resemble a task tool via a formatting box editor.
  - US regulators have approved Wegovy in pill form for weight loss, potentially expanding access and reducing costs.
  - Amazon is testing AI shopping agents and considering how to balance data access with data protection, influencing competitive dynamics.
  - Waymo and human responders are needed when robotaxis get stuck, illustrating new human-in-the-loop work for automated transportation.
New Tools:
  - [SPONSORED] DELVE CUA: a computer-using AI agent that automates compliance screenshot capture and attachment to controls for end-to-end documentation.
  - Windsurf Wave 13 update adds multi-agent sessions, Git worktrees, and a side-by-side agent monitoring UI.
  - URL Pattern API defines a cross-device URL pattern matching syntax with capturing groups for extraction.
  - Ruby 4.0.0 release introduces Ruby Box for isolated definitions and ZJIT, a faster just-in-time compiler.
  - CLAUDE HOW TO (GitHub repo): a complete guide to Claude Code features.
Insights:
  - No meaningful content.

emails.sender: "Dr. Alex Wissner-Gross from The Innermost Loop" <theinnermostloop@substack.com>
emails.subject: Welcome to December 26, 2025
emails.body:
View this post on the web at https://theinnermostloop.substack.com/p/welcome-to-december-26-2025

The yardstick has snapped. The ARC Prize Foundation has declared the saturation of the ARC-AGI-1 and ARC-AGI-2 benchmarks [ https://substack.com/redirect/6dec2b2f-2fc9-4b18-8cb5-dd3aaf3bbc94?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], admitting that current tests can no longer bound the fluid intelligence of the frontier. The goalposts have been moved to ‚ÄúMillennium Problem‚Äù complexity, effectively conceding that the next benchmark for AI is not human exams, but the unsolved limits of mathematics itself. This cognitive escape velocity is matched by physical recursion. In Beijing, Linkerbot humanoids are assembling and testing their own hands [ https://substack.com/redirect/1bd124db-cfaf-43fd-90bd-6693ad1b0e5f?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], creating a closed loop of robotic self-replication that previews the coming von Neumann machines. The cycle is tightening everywhere: the NanoGPT training speedrun has smashed the two-minute barrier at 119.3 seconds [ https://substack.com/redirect/e0daeed5-b64d-449a-a33a-7016ead44403?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], reducing model genesis to a rounding error.
The labor market is processing the obsolescence of code. US programmer employment has dropped 27.5% in two years [ https://substack.com/redirect/9de23e19-7e84-4ead-a124-6d8fce820897?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], a brutal confirmation that software development as we know it may no longer be a long-term human career. But it‚Äôs not just programming. DeepMind co-founder Shane Legg predicts all remote work will vanish within a decade [ https://substack.com/redirect/a8f49c0e-3ba2-48e6-bf55-8af624d2cc5c?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], displaced by agents. The vacuum is being filled by capital. The AI sector minted 50 new billionaires this year [ https://substack.com/redirect/330521fc-e1e5-4fbe-aec7-fadb0dba834b?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] as it captured 50% of all global venture funding. Venture capital is mutating into infrastructure finance; ex-a16z partner Anjney Midha is raising $10 billion to build a single gigawatt of AI capacity [ https://substack.com/redirect/0a452a6e-64cf-4685-a2fa-5655ba0a114e?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ]. Meanwhile, crypto has institutionalized; M&A deals hit $8.6 billion [ https://substack.com/redirect/fde26a54-ac8b-49de-a67a-18c49738f1ac?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] as the sector consolidates into the establishment.
Thanks for reading The Innermost Loop! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.
The architecture of thought is being refined. J√ºrgen Schmidhuber has unveiled PoPE (Polar Coordinate Positional Embedding) [ https://substack.com/redirect/aba7c3ed-5d11-4d7c-b660-31a00d5e34cb?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], a geometric fix to the Transformer that boosts performance on everything from genomics to symbolic music. DeepMind is targeting a time skip, focusing on scientific problems where AI can fast-forward progress by a decade [ https://substack.com/redirect/5c85ecfc-f809-44ff-add8-c9f65b44aaa0?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ].
The intelligence deployment gap is closing. OpenAI has declared a ‚Äúcapability overhang‚Äù [ https://substack.com/redirect/f68c077a-bce7-4ff9-b7bd-38cf499f0c04?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] between model potential and actual usage by consumers, apparently interpreting this lag as a signal to push reasoning models more aggressively into healthcare, business, and daily life in 2026. At the same time, the user base is shifting. Gemini now reportedly claims 20% of traffic [ https://substack.com/redirect/c06a0e3c-c4c7-4ce1-a6c0-38b602da8ee6?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], while Grok has taken the lead in time-spent metrics [ https://substack.com/redirect/f9421a4e-f518-481b-9b1e-a02b896f8b67?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ].
The silicon food chain has inverted. Nvidia is projected to displace Apple as TSMC‚Äôs largest customer in 2026 [ https://substack.com/redirect/32431ac6-f354-4b58-aee7-22fb387fded4?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], accounting for 20% of revenue. The market is already rewarding the new king. Nvidia‚Äôs $20 billion Groq acquisition paid for itself overnight [ https://substack.com/redirect/5e6a3b05-0f85-4fa3-8d32-4c0d2d15729e?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] as Nvidia‚Äôs market cap jumped more than $30 billion. Bank of America forecasts the chip sector will breach $1 trillion in sales next year [ https://substack.com/redirect/f7fda923-013c-40b8-ac7c-ca3ce3ddd15a?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ]. But the bottleneck remains memory. US hyperscalers have started firing executives who fail to secure High Bandwidth Memory [ https://substack.com/redirect/7d900f19-f55e-4f2d-8865-23b29da2dcce?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], stationing replacements in South Korea to plead for supply.
Energy is finding new vectors. China‚Äôs latest maglev test reached a record 700 km/h in two seconds [ https://substack.com/redirect/68125e64-b424-4253-97c3-fc3942149307?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] on a 400-meter track, demonstrating acceleration capabilities that hint at electromagnetic launch systems for aerospace. Offshore, Samsung Heavy Industries won U.S. approval for a floating nuclear power platform [ https://substack.com/redirect/f5ec0b1e-f66c-403e-86fb-12dc96b3259c?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] equipped with modular reactors, designed to power desalination or remote data centers for 60 years. The grid is greening by force. China is enforcing the world‚Äôs first mandatory EV energy efficiency standard [ https://substack.com/redirect/b40bafa0-aa57-494d-91dd-6f10c7fdd3f8?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] starting in 2026, while nine European nations have passed 25% EV adoption [ https://substack.com/redirect/0c7e17d5-20b4-4577-a943-785c990b2738?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ].
Safety is becoming superhuman. Elon Musk predicts Tesla FSD will be 100x safer than humans [ https://substack.com/redirect/3f5fc8aa-7a93-4815-9ee5-a34f43885ee3?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] in five years, while Garmin‚Äôs Autoland successfully landed a plane near Denver in an emergency [ https://substack.com/redirect/eb2a2b44-38e3-4844-b469-a0dcda240f13?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ] with passengers on board, a world first for autonomous aviation in a crisis. Yet human labor persists, for now, on the margins. Waymo is paying gig workers to manually close robotaxi doors [ https://substack.com/redirect/2b4e62f8-104d-48cd-adee-1b354c29280e?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ].
We are gaining full write access to biology. Columbia researchers demonstrated the first programmable in-vivo DNA methylation editing [ https://substack.com/redirect/6b6b32c4-579c-43db-aa89-92dc7822df45?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], allowing precise epigenetic control. The geography of discovery is also shifting; Goldman Sachs reports that China now originates 25% of innovative drug candidates [ https://substack.com/redirect/77ac7cb1-dfad-4ca7-92b0-b1546e0a288e?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], driving nearly half of global licensing deals.
Capital has decided to terraform the Solar System. SpaceX is now valued at $800 billion [ https://substack.com/redirect/d0467a99-24e4-4cd4-8026-d5cd30620492?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], worth more than the top six US defense firms combined, and Elon is promising 100-ton payloads to orbit in 2026 [ https://substack.com/redirect/fbcc3ad3-241b-4755-9bb6-b00e77b2c769?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ].
Meanwhile, for the last year, a German court has prevented robots from working in supermarkets on Sundays [ https://substack.com/redirect/50fb023c-428e-4e99-84a2-75d81afb7d2b?j=eyJ1IjoiM2k0dGc0In0.vvpuwnTV6tjkPeJI4GvgD6idI0-IwG2zWlmEaq0sXXI ], citing a 1,700-year-old decree by Emperor Constantine.
The Singularity, however, does not take days off.
Thanks for reading The Innermost Loop! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

Unsubscribe https://substack..Z3mxl_l5h37loM8yfkeRMRSLnK_MtlDGWsbBQxZwMxc?

emails.subject: üò∫ Why you underestimated China (and why you shouldn't)
emails.body:
View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/a0340727-143a-480c-bc07-a9a4d6be65fa/Gemini_Generated_Image_50h9bh50h9bh50h9.png?t=1766487455)
Caption: 

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/acfcf18c-6706-4f3d-b440-a52a98060cc4/IIn_Parnetship_with__2_.png?t=1766084419)
Follow image link: (https://link.technologyadvice.com/r/descript-nl-the-neuron-dec-25)
Caption: 

Welcome, humans. 

Turns out, robots are really good at installing solar panels. Like, suspiciously good.

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/c52b5d67-2687-47f3-8286-6276f3a14dff/Screenshot_2025-12-22_at_11.01.07_AM.png?t=1766476663)
Follow image link: (https://www.reddit.com/r/robotics/comments/1ps2aw1/in_china_robots_are_now_handling_the_solar_panels/)
Caption: 

Chinese solar farms are now using robotic arms to handle panel installation‚Äîfaster, safer, and without coffee breaks. Meanwhile, Japanese startup [GITAI](https://gitai.tech/) just [field-tested construction robots](https://www.reddit.com/r/robotics/comments/1pswpjv/gitais_rovers_and_robotic_arms_deploy_solar/) that can deploy panels AND weld in outdoor conditions.

**Here's the part that got my attention: **the systems use flexible positioning to adapt to uneven terrain, meaning they don't need perfectly flat land. That's huge for scaling renewable energy in, you know, places that aren't parking lots.

The Reddit robotics community is torn between ‚Äúthis is extremely practical‚Äú and ‚Äúwait, these are the same robots we said would never work outdoors three years ago.‚Äú _Progress moves fast when there's a $500B solar market at stake!_

**Here‚Äôs what happened in AI today: **

* OpenAI launched ChatGPT group chats for up to 20 people across all plan tiers.

* TSMC accelerated overseas chipmaking to reduce Taiwan invasion risk.

* OpenAI won't reach profitability until 2029 as platform losses mount.

* Everbloom deployed AI to convert waste fibers into new fabrics

Advertise in The Neuron here! (https://info.technologyadvice.com/advertise-with-the-neuron)

_**Don‚Äôt forget: **__Check out our podcast, The Neuron: AI Explained on _[_Spotify_](https://open.spotify.com/show/4gF6uNmkzEYq2E0sHeuMuU)_, _[_Apple Podcasts_](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-neuron-ai-explained/id1742267001)_, and _[_YouTube_](https://www.youtube.com/@theneuronai)_ ‚Äî new episodes air every week on Tuesdays after 2pm PST! _

‚Äú**P.S: **We still need your help shaping The Neuron in 2026‚Äîand we're willing to bribe you for it. Take our [3-minute, 20-question survey](https://www.theneurondaily.com/forms/f0475c6a-e314-406d-9c9b-1c2b6b47ffd0) to tell us what you actually want (More tutorials? Deep dives? Live events? More Interviews? Less of Grant's idiosyncratic diatribes? MORE of Grant‚Äôs idiosyncratic diatribes?!?) 

The first **1000 people** to finish enter to win a **$500 gift card** and a **free 1-hour consult** with Grant and Corey.

Your feedback will literally build our roadmap for 2026, so don't hold back. [Full terms here](https://www.theneurondaily.com/c/neuron-2026-survey-terms?utm_source=www.theneurondaily.com&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=is-gemini-flash-3-intelligence-too-cheap-to-meter&_bhlid=42573c08311e1ee742cb499718a1431d8c5f3ab1).‚Äú ‚Äî 

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/6a4266bb-f638-4a6b-9d48-8eafccfdebfb/image.png?t=1765839660)
Caption: 

# ChatGPT Group Chats Are Here‚Ä¶ Here‚Äôs What We Think

OpenAI recently rolled out [group chats globally](https://openai.com/index/group-chats-in-chatgpt/) after a week-long pilot in four countries. Up to 20 people can now collaborate with ChatGPT in shared conversations across all plan tiers: Free, Go, Plus, and Pro.

**The feature works like you'd expect:** 

* Tap the people icon, share an invite link, and everyone can chat together with ChatGPT jumping in when needed. 

* You can @ mention it for responses, set custom instructions for tone, and ChatGPT even reacts with emojis. 

* Privacy-first design means your personal memory stays separate from group chats.

Early feedback from pilot markets shows strong adoption for specific use cases like research teams and trip planning, but questions remain about scaling beyond small groups.

**Our Experience:** We tested it out on one of our lives the other day, and had a about 6 of us chatting at one point. Samuel joined from Nairobi, Corey was in St. Louis, and ChatGPT calculated we were 8,150 miles apart in the chat; then we had it tell us it would take a triathlete 23 days nonstop to cover that distance.

I didn't really get the appeal at first. ChatGPT wouldn't shut up unless we explicitly @ mentioned it, which got annoying. But goofing off with friends while an intelligent AI bot chimed in? That was genuinely fun; like having a smart Discord bot or Reddit reply bot you can summon on command.

The problem? The ultimate form factor for this _isn't_ ChatGPT‚Ä¶ it's _iMessage_, where I'm already texting my friends. OpenAI needs to figure out how to get ChatGPT into my existing messaging apps, not ask me to move my entire social life into their app.

**Here's why this matters:** The Information [recently reported](https://www.theinformation.com/articles/openais-organizational-problems-hurt-chatgpt) that OpenAI leaders are concerned the average user won't see much difference between ChatGPT and Gemini. 

More importantly, they noted that chatbots fundamentally lack the network effects that made Facebook and Instagram sticky, as those apps got better as more people joined; you can think of it as FB and IG being multiplayer games, while GPT is mostly single player‚Ä¶ _until NOW‚Ä¶ ish. _

**See, OpenAI's tried building network effects before: **

* Remember the GPT store? IMO it never really panned out, and now GPTs in general feel mostly deprecated with connectors and skills. 

* Sora [hit 1M downloads](https://techcrunch.com/2025/10/09/sora-hit-1m-downloads-faster-than-chatgpt/) faster than ChatGPT, and it's since found a loyal yet niche following‚Ä¶ but unless I missed it, nowhere near mass adoption. 

* The new [Apps marketplace](https://chatgpt.com/apps/) just launched, and remains to be seen whether it‚Äôll create the stickiness OpenAI needs.

IMO, the _actual_ network effects in AI come from **Projects** (Claude's killer feature, which GPT also has) and **Memories** (ChatGPT's killer feature, which Claude also has). 

Personally, I keep going back to Claude because that's where my projects with all my daily tasks live: it's my hub. For me, ChatGPT and Gemini are better for one-off questions and tasks, but Claude owns my workflow because of Projects. Other people feel the same way about ChatGPT Memories. [_Thanks for the memories_](https://youtu.be/onzL0EM1pKY?si=KFmFjj-2rjIjoM0m&t=88)_, sorry that they‚Äôre stuck in GPT! _

**So really, what would it take to build real network effects into AI assistants?** Here are a few ideas:

1. **iMessage integration**: Turn ChatGPT into a bot you can call in your existing group chats, not a separate app.

2. **AI-first marketplace?**: Imagine a Facebook Marketplace competitor where your AI agent finds items others are selling based on your preferences.

3. **YouTube-style playable features**: YouTube recently added playable games. What if ChatGPT had persistent, multiplayer experiences you could only access through the platform? That‚Äôs something I‚Äôd group chat about. 

4. **OpenAI's rumored hardware device**: A physical device that makes ChatGPT your default interface could create lock-in, especially if there‚Äôs a multiplayer component (_new communication interface to chat w/ friends?)_

5. **Collaborative workspaces that persist**: What if ChatGPT hosted persistent team workspaces that accumulated shared knowledge over time? _Right now, I‚Äôd settle for a Canvas file that doesn‚Äôt get context constrained‚Ä¶ _

**Why this matters:** AI companies are realizing chatbots alone won't create defensible moats. The winner won't be the smartest model; it'll be whoever figures out how to embed AI into either A) the workflows and social networks we can't quit, or B) new workflows that are even better than previous ones. 

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/7cf99573-4593-460e-bb90-7154a8d863f4/image.png?t=1765839774)
Caption: 

**FROM OUR PARTNERS**

# Your last video edit took 4 hours. This one will take 4 minutes.

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/321fa7a3-883e-4ae5-ae71-20da16ce8aff/Neuron_AffiliateCreative_1225_DescriptAd1.png?t=1766085073)
Follow image link: (https://link.technologyadvice.com/r/descript-nl-the-neuron-dec-25)
Caption: 

You recorded the perfect take. Then you said ‚Äúum‚Äú 47 times, lost eye contact reading your notes, and the audio sounds like you're calling from inside a tin can.

**Here's the problem:** traditional video editors make you hunt through timelines finding every filler word. That's 3-4 hours of tedious clicking for a 20-minute video.

[Descript](https://link.technologyadvice.com/r/descript-nl-the-neuron-dec-25) flips everything. Upload your video, and AI transcribes it instantly. Delete words from the transcript, and the video edits itself. Type ‚Äúremove all ums‚Äú and they vanish. One click cleans your audio to studio quality. Another fixes your eye contact.

100+ sales teams already save 15+ hours weekly on video editing.

[**Edit your first video in minutes ‚Üí**](https://link.technologyadvice.com/r/descript-nl-the-neuron-dec-25)

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/e5794086-ccbb-4d09-b13a-c384b3421010/image.png?t=1765839639)
Caption: 

# Prompt Tip of the Day 

Get an editor _and_ a rewrite without losing your voice.

Most ‚Äúrewrite this‚Äù prompts accidentally swap your intent for the model‚Äôs. This one prevents that by forcing a diagnosis first (what‚Äôs wrong and why), then a fix, plus a few stylistic options so you can choose the version that fits the moment.

```
The ‚ÄúCritique and Upgrade My Draft‚Äù Prompt 

Improve this without changing my intent. 
List the top 5 issues (clarity, structure, missing info, tone). 
Rewrite it. 
Provide 3 alternatives: shorter, more direct, more friendly. 
Draft: [paste]
```
**BONUS: **After the rewrite, give me a 1-sentence subject line (if relevant) and highlight any sentences you changed the most, with a quick reason.

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/31dbfaac-0721-4c34-b8e5-557c4a7cb3ca/image.png?t=1765839671)
Caption: 

# Treats to Try 

_*Asterisk = from our partners (only the first one!). __[Advertise to 600K readers here](https://info.technologyadvice.com/advertise-with-the-neuron)__!_

1. [TwelveLabs](https://www.twelvelabs.io/) turns your video library into something you can search and summarize in plain English (e.g., ‚Äúfind every clip where the CEO mentions pricing‚Äù) (raised $30M) ‚Äîfree to try, then usage-based.

2. [Koah](https://www.koahlabs.com/) lets you plug contextual ads directly into your chat app so you can monetize conversations without forcing subscriptions.

3. [Higgsfield](https://higgsfield.ai/) helps you generate short cinematic videos and ads without editing everything by hand.

4. [Devin](https://devin.ai/) acts like a software teammate that can take a ticket, write the code, run tests, and open the PR for you.

5. [Windsurf](https://windsurf.com/) is a code editor where you ask for a change in plain English and it applies the edits inline while you preview what you‚Äôre building.

6. [NotebookLM Reports](https://notebooklm.google/) turns your uploaded sources into structured outputs like a study guide, glossary, or blog-style writeup so you can go from ‚Äúpile of PDFs‚Äù to ‚Äúshareable doc‚Äù fast ‚Äîfree to try.

7. [Agent Skills](https://github.com/anthropics/skills) is a repo of installable ‚Äúskill packs‚Äù Claude loads dynamically (instructions + scripts + resources).

8. [Agent Skills docs](https://platform.claude.com/docs/en/agents-and-tools/agent-skills/overview) shows how to package reusable skill folders that Claude loads progressively on demand.

9. [claude-mem](https://github.com/thedotmack/claude-mem) captures what Claude Code did in your session, compresses it, and injects relevant context into future sessions so it stops forgetting.

10. [Foundations of LLMs](https://github.com/ZJU-LLMs/Foundations-of-LLMs) is a monthly-updated, paper-linked textbook repo that covers the practical core (prompting, PEFT, editing, RAG) plus how architectures evolved.

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/abf3b639-ca99-484e-992a-9cf6d8687a54/image.png?t=1765839770)
Caption: 

# Around the Horn 

1. [TSMC sped up](https://www.semafor.com/article/12/19/2025/taiwan-ramps-up-plans-for-overseas-chipmaking-as-threat-from-china-looms) advanced chipmaking overseas to reduce global exposure to a Taiwan invasion scenario.

2. [Everbloom](https://www.semafor.com/article/12/17/2025/new-york-based-startup-uses-ai-to-recycle-scrap-materials-into-fabrics) used an AI model to tune machines/chemistry that turn waste fibers into new fabrics.

3. [OpenAI](https://techxplore.com/news/2025-12-openai-tech-giant-netscape.html)‚Äôs platform bet is a race between distribution and economics (losses for years; profitability not expected before 2029; enormous infra commitments).

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/a000e4e0-4bc0-400d-8af9-0777155f6578/image.png?t=1765839850)
Caption: 

**FROM OUR PARTNERS **

# Agents that don‚Äôt suck

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/d95beb4a-11c2-4a1f-902b-4472ddc06b7f/neuron-newsletter-build-evaluate-optimize-1450x530.gif?t=1765981960)
Follow image link: (https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N2655160.1896899TECHNOLOGYADVICE/B34639274.434876476;dc_trk_aid=628814391;dc_trk_cid=246304364;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;gdpr=${GDPR};gdpr_consent=${GDPR_CONSENT_755};ltd=;dc_tdv=1)
Caption: 

Getting agents to production takes accuracy, reliability and your unique data. Agent Bricks helps you build powerful agents grounded in your data and proven to work. It evaluates agents automatically with metrics tailored to your goals. With continuous self-learning and human feedback, agents keep learning and quality keeps improving.

[**See how Agent Bricks works**](https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N2655160.1896899TECHNOLOGYADVICE/B34639274.434876476;dc_trk_aid=628814391;dc_trk_cid=246304364;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;gdpr=${GDPR};gdpr_consent=${GDPR_CONSENT_755};ltd=;dc_tdv=1)

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/c8f9d58e-efb0-48ea-a3e4-1397bafab601/image.png?t=1765839750)
Caption: 

# Intelligent Insights 

1. [Transformer economics](https://aleximas.substack.com/p/can-a-transformer-learn-economic) argued transformers weaken (but don‚Äôt erase) the Lucas Critique by generalizing across nearby policy regimes better than reduced-form regressions‚Äîwhile still missing key causal dynamics when shocks propagate.

2. [Prompt caching](https://ngrok.com/blog/prompt-caching) argued KV reuse is the real trick: once a prefix is cached, models skip recomputing attention for it‚Äîcutting cost and time-to-first-token on repeated long prompts.

3. [Off-policy RL mismatch](https://fengyao.notion.site/off-policy-rl#28b721e3f6c480c3a756f8fb319e860d) argued inference/training backend mismatch turns ‚Äúon-policy‚Äù LLM RL into biased off-policy updates, and proposed token-level truncated importance sampling (TIS) as a systems-level patch.

4. [Limit of RLVR](https://limit-of-rlvr.github.io/) argued 0/1-reward RLVR mostly squeezes more correct samples out of a base model rather than expanding its reasoning boundary‚Äîso the next breakthroughs likely need richer rewards and stronger exploration.

5. [AI consciousness](https://techxplore.com/news/2025-12-ai-conscious-philosopher.html) argued we may never be able to test AI consciousness (so agnosticism is rational) and warned the ethically relevant line is sentience‚Äîwhile ‚Äúconscious AI‚Äù talk can become marketing.

6. [Democrats‚Äô divide](https://www.axios.com/2025/12/21/ai-fight-democrats-2028) argued AI is becoming a 2028 wedge issue inside the party, pitting innovation-first messaging against labor-first regulation as automation anxiety rises.

7. [Excel AI-proof](https://www.semafor.com/article/12/12/2025/why-excel-is-ai-proof) argued Excel‚Äôs ecosystem moats + math reliability keep it sticky‚Äîso Microsoft is embedding models into Excel and making spreadsheets the substrate for agents.

8. [Google + Replit](https://venturebeat.com/orchestration/even-google-and-replit-struggle-to-deploy-ai-agents-reliably-heres-why) argued the hard part of agents is reliability and integration (not intelligence): messy data and deterministic workflows don‚Äôt mix with probabilistic systems.

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/9bb84f71-8556-4c4b-8fc2-b98c936e9850/image.png?t=1765839615)
Caption: 

# A Cat‚Äôs Commentary 

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/07f28d91-ec80-47bd-9aa8-5fbf69f8e047/A_Cat_s_Commentary_x_2025_-_2025-12-14T104935.610.png?t=1766441870)
Caption: No, thank YOU

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/93ec8c01-d7e4-4782-b01c-2f4ac1619548/image.png?t=1765839706)
Caption: 

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/a91e1dde-2674-4f02-9770-8dc0e804d697/image.png?t=1764643057)
Caption: 

That‚Äôs all for now. 






**P.S: **Before you go‚Ä¶ have you subscribed to our[ YouTube Channel](https://www.youtube.com/@theneuronai?sub_confirmation=1)? If not, could you?

View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/a24710a5-002e-463c-b79d-f5754a0e8e59/Gemini_Generated_Image_c6yadmc6yadmc6ya.png?t=1764928014)
Follow image link: (https://www.youtube.com/@theneuronai?sub_confirmation=1)
Caption: Click the image to subscribe! 

**P.P.S:** Love [the newsletter](https://www.theneurondaily.com/), but only want to get it once per week? Don‚Äôt unsubscribe‚Äî[update your preferences here](https://www.theneurondaily.com/subscribe/f5596641-9099-4045-9641-731cd9fdcf90/preferences).  


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

You are reading a plain text version of this post. For the best experience, copy and paste this link in your browser to view the post online:
https://www.theneurondaily.com/p/groupchats-in-chatgpt-here-s-what-we-think

emails.subject: Gmail address changes üìß, ChatGPT formatting blocks ü§ñ, Ruby 4 ‚ô¶Ô∏è
emails.body:
Google is gradually rolling out the option to change a Gmail address
to a new one (up to three times) with an altered
username¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†


 Sign Up [1] |Advertise [2]|View Online [3] 

		TLDR 

		TOGETHER WITH [Delve] [4]

TLDR 2025-12-26

 DELVE SHIPMAS DAY 5: AUTOMATED SCREENSHOTS WITH DELVE CUA (SPONSOR)
[4] 

 Welcome to the final day of DELVE SHIPMAS üéÑ¬†We've announced an AI
copilot, AI-native VRM, an AI security questionnaire extension,
all-new frameworks, and now: CUA.

If you've ever spent hours: clicking through dashboards, taking
screenshots, labeling files, and then re-doing it all again for the
next audit.

‚Ä¶this one's for you. Today, Delve is launching DELVE CUA: a
COMPUTER-USING AI AGENT THAT TAKES COMPLIANCE SCREENSHOTS FOR YOU.

Delve's agent securely navigates your tools, captures screenshots at
the right moments, and attaches them directly to the correct controls,
while you focus on actually building security.

You build. Delve documents. That's compliance, finally automated
end-to-end.

Trusted by 1,000+ OF THE FASTEST-GROWING COMPANIES, including 11x,
Instantly, micro1, Wisprflow, Greptile, Browser Use, and more.

üëâ BOOK A DEMO here [4] to see Delve CUA in action and get $1,500
OFF with code DELVEXMAS5.

üì± 

BIG TECH & STARTUPS

 GOOGLE SAYS IT IS ‚ÄòGRADUALLY ROLLING OUT' OPTION TO CHANGE YOUR
@GMAIL.COM ADDRESS (4 MINUTE READ) [5] 

 Google is gradually rolling out the option to change a Gmail address
to a new one (up to three times) with an altered username. Users'
original email address will still receive emails and work for sign-in.
Users will be unable to change or delete their email within 12 months
of each change. The support page detailing the update is currently
only in Hindi. 

 CHATGPT'S NEW FORMATTING BLOCKS MAKE ITS UI LOOK MORE LIKE A TASK
TOOL (2 MINUTE READ) [6] 

 OpenAI has quietly rolled out a new feature that tweaks ChatGPT's
layout to match the UI of the task it is supposed to execute. The new
'formatting box' mini editor toolbar pops up when users highlight text
inside ChatGPT's newer rich-text areas. It shows drafts as formatted
documents so users can edit them as they would in any document editor.
A screenshot of the feature is available in the article. 

üöÄ 

SCIENCE & FUTURISTIC TECHNOLOGY

 US REGULATORS APPROVE WEGOVY PILL FOR WEIGHT LOSS (5 MINUTE READ) [7]


 A pill version of Wegovy has been approved in the US to treat
obesity. The ability of oral pills could expand the market by
broadening access and reducing costs. The pills are expected to be
available within weeks. The starting dose will be available for $149
per month from some providers. Additional information on cost will be
released in January. 

 NASA WILL SOON FIND OUT IF THE PERSEVERANCE ROVER CAN REALLY
PERSEVERE ON MARS (13 MINUTE READ) [8] 

 Perseverance arrived on Mars nearly five years ago. At the time, NASA
had planned a mission to retrieve samples collected by the rover as
soon as 2026, but now, no such mission is set to launch until the
2030s. Perseverance appears to be in good condition and should be able
to operate for many years to come. The rover will continue filling
sample tubes in the expectation that they will eventually come back to
Earth. 

üíª 

PROGRAMMING, DESIGN & DATA SCIENCE

 URL PATTERN API (17 MINUTE READ) [9] 

 The URL Pattern API defines a syntax that is used to create URL
pattern matchers. Patterns are specified using the URLPattern
interface with a pattern syntax based on the syntax from the
path-to-regexp library. They can contain capturing groups that extract
parts of the matched URL. The API works across all of the latest
devices and browser versions. 

 RUBY 4.0.0 RELEASED (23 MINUTE READ) [10] 

 Ruby 4.0 introduces Ruby Box and ZJIT and adds many improvements.
Ruby Box is a feature that provides separations about definitions.
Definitions loaded in a box are isolated in the box. ZJIT is a new
just-in-time compiler developed to raise the performance ceiling and
encourage more outside contributions. It is faster than the
interpreter, but not yet as fast as YJIT. 

üéÅ 

MISCELLANEOUS

 AMAZON FACES ‚ÄòLEADER'S DILEMMA' ‚Äî FIGHT AI SHOPPING BOTS OR JOIN
THEM (7 MINUTE READ) [11] 

 Amazon is using its subsidiaries to experiment with shopping agents
as it continues to contemplate how to deal with them. While the
company may be willing to let agents access its catalog, it likely
wants to protect more valuable data, such as reviews, from its
competitors. Its homegrown AI tools have improved since they first
launched. Amazon is now testing an agent that can purchase products
from other sites directly in its e-commerce app. 

 WHEN ROBOT TAXIS GET STUCK, A SECRET ARMY OF HUMANS COMES TO THE
RESCUE (6 MINUTE READ) [12] 

 Waymo vehicles become stranded if a human doesn't close the door
behind them at the end of a ride. Riders and passerbys are unreliable,
so Waymo summons help through an app called Honk, paying workers $20
or more for rescuing a robotaxi by closing a door. Last weekend's
power outage in San Francisco resulted in a severe gridlock throughout
the city, causing a flurry of requests for tow-truck companies to
retrieve Waymo vehicles. These are examples of how, as automation
advances, it can create new work for humans to fix errors.
